title: Preparations for Madrid retreat with family

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The morning light filters through the tall windows of the royal apartments as Doña Beatriz finishes dressing Catalina in a warm wool travelling gown of deep blue—the color that matches her father's eyes, the seamstresses always say. The little princess, now nearly twenty months old, has been informed that she will be going on a journey with Papá and Lucia-mama, and her excitement manifests in an inability to sit still for even a moment.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Horses?

exchanges.speaker: beatriz
exchanges.text: Yes, mi pequeña, there will be horses.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: In the adjoining chamber, servants are packing the lighter items—clothing, toys, the carved wooden animals Catalina refuses to sleep without. Donna Francesca oversees the Italian ladies' preparations in the Queen's apartments, ensuring Lucia's travelling wardrobe includes both practical riding clothes and appropriate attire for a royal arrival, modest though Madrid may be.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. The advance party departed at first light—twelve men to ensure the road is clear and the royal hunting lodge prepared. The main escort will be ready within the hour. Forty men-at-arms should be sufficient for the journey. Madrid is only thirteen leagues from Toledo—we should arrive well before nightfall if we depart by mid-morning.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The road north follows the Tagus for a time before cutting across the gentle hills of the Castilian plateau. Madrid itself sits on the Manzanares River, a modest town that serves primarily as a waystation on the road north to Burgos and as an occasional hunting retreat for Castilian kings. The royal lodge there, while far smaller than the Alcázar of Toledo, has the advantage of relative simplicity—fewer courtiers, fewer demands, more time with family.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Prince Fernando will remain here with the wet nurse and his household. The physicians advise against travel for an infant in winter, even so short a distance. Doña Beatriz has volunteered to remain and oversee his care. The Queen's Italian ladies are debating amongst themselves who shall accompany her and who shall remain. I am told the discussion has been... spirited.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Queen's apartments are in a state of controlled chaos when you arrive. Trunks stand open, gowns draped over chairs, and the six Italian ladies are engaged in what appears to be a vigorous negotiation conducted in rapid Ferrarese dialect—too fast for your Castilian-trained ear to follow entirely, though you catch fragments about the road in winter and someone remaining with the prince.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_d_este
exchanges.text: Ah. My husband arrives to find his household in disarray. I told them two may accompany us and four must remain. You would think I had asked them to choose which of their sisters to throw from a tower.

exchanges.speaker: donna_francesca
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, we are merely ensuring the Queen's comfort is properly attended to. Madrid is a small town—

exchanges.speaker: lucia_d_este
exchanges.text: Madrid is a hunting lodge. We are not receiving ambassadors. We are taking Catalina to see snow, if God grants us any, and giving my husband a week without councilors asking him to sign things. Francesca and Isabella will come—Francesca because she will sulk for a month if I leave her, and Isabella because she rides well and complains little. The others will remain to terrorize Fernando's household and ensure the Alcázar does not collapse in our absence.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_d_este
exchanges.text: Horses only suits me well. Carriages crawl, and thirteen leagues in a swaying box sounds like a recipe for a miserable child and a headache for everyone within earshot. Catalina can ride with us in turns. She is light enough that neither horse will notice the difference, and she will be happier being passed between us than strapped into a litter watching the world go by without her.

exchanges.speaker: donna_francesca
exchanges.text: Your Majesties, if I may—the Princess is not yet two years old. Thirteen leagues is a full day's journey. She will need to sleep at some point, and sleeping on horseback at a trot...

exchanges.speaker: lucia_d_este
exchanges.text: Then we stop when she sleeps. We are not racing to lift a siege. If we arrive an hour later because Catalina needed to nap in someone's arms under a tree, the hunting lodge will not collapse from the delay. We should bring extra cloaks for her—it will be colder on the plateau than here in the valley. And something to eat that she can manage on horseback. She will also inform us, very loudly, when she wishes to switch horses. I do not think we will need to guess.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You leave Lucia to the final negotiations among her ladies and return to your own chambers, where your travelling clothes have been laid out—a practical wool doublet in Castilian crimson, leather riding boots worn soft from years of use, and a heavy cloak lined with fur against the December chill. No crown, no chains of office. Today you are simply a man taking his family north. Hidalgo is waiting in the courtyard, breath steaming in the cold morning air. The great destrier stamps and tosses his head when he sees you, eager for the road after too many weeks of stable rest.

encounters.recap: Juan prepares for a family retreat to Madrid with Lucia and Catalina. They decide to travel on horseback rather than by carriage, with Catalina riding alternately with her parents. Álvaro arranges a forty-man escort while the Italian ladies debate who will accompany the Queen. Fernando remains in Toledo under Beatriz's care.

roll.outcome: Pleasant Journey. Crisp, clear winter day—cold but bright, with good visibility across the plateau. Catalina is delighted by everything, chattering happily, and behaves beautifully. The party makes good time, arriving before expected. A genuinely enjoyable ride.

encounters.recap: The royal family's journey from Toledo to Madrid proceeds under ideal conditions—a bright, crisp December day with Princess Catalina proving an exemplary traveler, delighting in everything she sees and behaving perfectly throughout the ride.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The road north unfolds beneath a crisp December sky—cold but bright, the winter sun hanging low and pale over the Castilian plateau. The air bites at exposed skin, but there is no wind to speak of, and the horses' breath rises in steady white plumes as they maintain an easy pace.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina proves an ideal travelling companion. She spends the first hour on Hidalgo with you, clutching his mane and providing commentary on everything she sees: "Trees, Papá. Big trees." Then, imperiously: "Birds." When a hawk circles overhead, she points with her riding crop and announces, "That one." As if claiming it for her personal collection.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: By mid-morning she demands transfer to Lucia, reaching out with grabbing hands until you pass her across. She settles against Lucia on Tormenta with a contented sigh, and within minutes is drowsing against her stepmother's chest, lulled by the rhythm of hoofbeats.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You stop briefly at a village well to water the horses. Catalina wakes, eats dried apricots with intense concentration, shares one with Donna Francesca (who accepts it gravely, as one receives a gift from royalty), and declares herself ready to ride with Papá again.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The plateau stretches around you—brown winter grass, scattered holm oaks, the distant blue suggestion of the Guadarrama mountains to the north. Captain Fernán's scouts report the road clear ahead. The men-at-arms ride in relaxed formation, some talking quietly among themselves.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: By early afternoon, the modest towers of Madrid come into view—a small town climbing a gentle hill above the Manzanares River, the royal hunting lodge visible on its outskirts. You arrive with perhaps two hours of daylight remaining, Catalina still chattering happily about horses and birds and the "big water" of the river.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The lodge steward emerges to greet you, bowing deeply. Smoke rises from multiple chimneys—fires already lit, rooms prepared. The smell of roasting meat drifts from somewhere within. A genuinely enjoyable ride. A family, travelling together.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: What do you think Lucia? When we travel to Valencia as part of our trip to Rome, should we travel like this as well?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia shifts Catalina on her hip—your daughter has demanded to be carried into the lodge and is currently examining Lucia's braid with intense scholarly interest, occasionally tugging to test its structural integrity.

roll.outcome: Pleasant Journey. Crisp, clear winter day—cold but bright, with good visibility across the plateau. Catalina is delighted by everything, chattering happily, and behaves beautifully. The party makes good time, arriving before expected. A genuinely enjoyable ride.

encounters.recap: The royal family enjoys a pleasant winter journey from Toledo to Madrid. Catalina proves an ideal traveling companion, delighting in everything she sees and behaving perfectly. The party arrives at the hunting lodge in good spirits with time to spare, finding warm fires and prepared rooms awaiting them.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: By early afternoon, the modest towers of Madrid come into view—a small town climbing a gentle hill above the Manzanares River, the royal hunting lodge visible on its outskirts. You arrive with perhaps two hours of daylight remaining, Catalina still chattering happily about horses and birds and the "big water" of the river. The lodge steward emerges to greet you, bowing deeply. Smoke rises from multiple chimneys—fires already lit, rooms prepared. The smell of roasting meat drifts from somewhere within.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: What do you think Lucia? When we travel to Valencia as part of our trip to Rome, should we travel like this as well?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia shifts Catalina on her hip—your daughter has demanded to be carried into the lodge and is currently examining Lucia's braid with intense scholarly interest, occasionally tugging to test its structural integrity.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Like this? Without the endless procession of wagons and the ceremonial nonsense? I would like that. But Valencia is not thirteen leagues across a friendly plateau. It is... what, sixty leagues? Seventy? Through lands where you are king and must be seen as king. When we passed through that village today—the one with the well—did you see how the people looked at you? Not with fear or ceremony. With... warmth. That man is our king, and he rides with his daughter like any father. That is worth something. Perhaps worth more than a hundred banners and a thousand outriders. But we will also have eight hundred crusaders, sacred relics, the treasury you are returning to the Pope, and half the court. That is not a family riding to a hunting lodge. That is a kingdom moving. I suspect simple is no longer available to us, husband. But perhaps we can find moments of it along the way. Stop at a village well. Let Catalina terrorize local chickens. Remind ourselves we are people, not only crowns. What are you truly asking? Whether I can endure the journey, or whether I will enjoy it?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Just trying to figure out if this is a mode of travel Catalina can endure for days on end.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Today she was happy. But today was also—what, six hours in the saddle? Seven? And she slept for part of it, ate when she wished, switched between us when she grew restless. One day, she is a delight. Two days, perhaps still manageable. But five days? Six? Day after day of rising early, riding until dark, sleeping in strange beds? Children are not small adults. They do not endure discomfort stoically and complain later in their memoirs. They endure it loudly, immediately, and repeatedly.

exchanges.speaker: donna_francesca
exchanges.text: If I may, Your Majesties—the journey to Valencia might be managed in stages. Ride some days, rest others. A litter or small carriage for the hours when she is tired or the weather turns foul, even if horses are preferred otherwise. Children need variety more than consistency on long journeys. The same thing for hours on end is what breaks them.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: And she will be five months older by spring. Walking more steadily, talking more, perhaps more... resilient? I confess I do not know what twenty-four-month-old children can endure. Ferrara did not prepare me for this particular question. We could also leave her in Toledo with Doña Beatriz and Fernando. It would be safer, simpler. But I do not think either of us wants that.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We will travel with a carriage for Catalina. She will have a need for shelter indeed and distractions. And space for adults to keep her company as well. I go to Catalina. So daughter. What do you think of this house?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina has been set down and is conducting a thorough inspection of the lodge's entrance hall, toddling from one point of interest to the next with the focused determination of a royal assessor evaluating a new acquisition.

encounters.recap: Upon arriving at the Madrid hunting lodge, Juan and Lucia discuss travel arrangements for their upcoming journey to Valencia and Rome. They consider whether to travel simply like a family or with full royal ceremony, ultimately deciding to bring Catalina along with a carriage for her comfort and safety during the longer journey ahead.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina has been set down and is conducting a thorough inspection of the lodge's entrance hall, toddling from one point of interest to the next with the focused determination of a royal assessor evaluating a new acquisition. At your question, she pauses her examination of a wooden chest—she had been attempting to lift its lid, without success—and looks around with exaggerated seriousness. Her gaze travels up the stone walls, across the modest timber ceiling, to the fireplace where flames crackle invitingly.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Small.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Donna Isabella stifles a laugh behind her hand. Lucia's lips twitch. Catalina is not finished with her assessment, however. She toddles to the fireplace, peers at it with approval, then points at the fire.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Warm.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She continues her circuit, patting a tapestry depicting a hunting scene—deer fleeing before hounds—and announces:

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Doggies.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Then, with evident concern, pointing at the deer:

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Running. Fast.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Finally she returns to you, craning her neck to look up. Her verdict seems to require careful consideration. She looks at the fire again, then at the tapestry, then at you.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Good.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Then, with the immediate pivot of toddler priorities:

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Hungry.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: From somewhere deeper in the lodge, the smell of roasting meat intensifies, as if the kitchen has heard and intends to comply with royal command.

encounters.recap: Princess Catalina conducts a thorough inspection of the Madrid hunting lodge, evaluating its modest size, warm fireplace, and hunting tapestries before declaring it 'good' and demanding food with characteristic toddler directness.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The lodge's great hall—though "great" is generous for a room perhaps a quarter the size of Toledo's—proves warm and surprisingly comfortable. A long oak table has been set near the fire, and the steward has done well with limited notice: roasted mutton, fresh bread, a pottage of winter vegetables, cheese from a local farm, and wine from somewhere south of Madrid that proves better than expected.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina is installed in a high-backed chair piled with cushions to bring her to table height, a arrangement she finds deeply satisfactory. She attacks her meal with enthusiasm—bread torn into small pieces, chunks of soft cheese, bits of mutton cut fine by Donna Francesca. The pottage she eyes with suspicion and refuses entirely, turning her face away with theatrical disgust when it is offered.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: No

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia eats with the easy appetite of someone who has spent a day in the saddle, occasionally passing Catalina a morsel or wiping her face with a cloth when the cheese becomes too ambitious. The Italian ladies sit at the far end of the table, speaking quietly in Ferrarese, while Captain Fernán takes his meal with the men-at-arms in an adjoining room.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: This is what I imagined. When you spoke of Madrid. Fewer people. Smaller rooms. Time to simply... be.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina's bread tower collapses. She looks at it with betrayal, then at you, clearly expecting you to fix this architectural disaster.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina looks at the collapsed bread, then at you, then back at the bread. The suggestion that she might eat her building materials appears to strike her as both novel and faintly scandalous. She picks up one piece, examines it with the gravity of a master mason inspecting a failed cornerstone, and takes a thoughtful bite. She chews. She considers.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Good

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The remaining pieces of the tower are consumed in short order, architectural ambitions abandoned in favor of more practical concerns. When the bread is gone, she looks at her empty hands with mild confusion, then at the table, clearly searching for more construction materials. Lucia pushes a small piece of cheese toward her. Catalina picks it up, studies it, and attempts to balance it on top of another piece of cheese. It falls immediately.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: No

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She eats it instead, the lesson apparently learned. By the time the meal winds down, Catalina's eyelids are growing heavy, her movements slower. She leans against the cushions, a crust of bread still clutched in one hand like a talisman against sleep. Her head begins to nod.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Someone has had a very long day on horseback.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Donna Francesca rises, ready to take Catalina to the small chamber prepared for her, but pauses—looking to you and Lucia to see if you wish to put her to bed yourselves.

roll.outcome: Early Winter 1434. Lucia conceives in January 1434, shortly after the Madrid retreat. Pregnancy confirmed by late February. Child due October 1434. Swift and reassuring for the kingdom.

encounters.recap: The royal family enjoys an intimate dinner at the Madrid hunting lodge. Young Catalina delights in building bread towers and refusing vegetables, while Juan and Lucia savor the quiet domesticity. A conception roll determines that Lucia will become pregnant in January 1434, with the child due in October.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Madrid retreat passes quietly. Days blur together in pleasant monotony: morning rides when the weather permits, Catalina's endless explorations of the lodge and its grounds, evenings by the fire with wine and conversation. The small household falls into easy rhythm—no ambassadors demanding audiences, no councils requiring decisions, no documents awaiting signature.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia blooms in the informal setting, her Ferrarese wit sharpening without the weight of court ceremony. You catch her one afternoon teaching Catalina Italian words for animals, your daughter solemnly repeating "cavallo" and "cane" with varying degrees of accuracy.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The days grow shorter, then slowly begin to lengthen again. Christmas comes and goes, celebrated simply in Madrid's small church. The new year arrives—1434, the year that will see you sail to Constantinople, the year your second child will be born.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: By mid-January, you must think of returning to Toledo. The kingdom awaits. The Constantinople expedition requires planning. The world will not hold still forever, even for kings who wish it would. But for now—for these few weeks—you are simply a man with his wife and daughter, in a small house, watching the fire burn low.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I make sure Catalina gets accustomed to the outside and riding regularly. I explain to her that we will go on a journey that will last many days and that Catalina should learn to ride a horse along with papa and Lucia.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina receives this news with the grave attention she reserves for matters of supreme importance—the same expression she wears when inspecting a new wooden animal or deciding whether a particular food is acceptable.

encounters.recap: The royal family enjoys a peaceful winter retreat at the Madrid hunting lodge, away from court pressures. Lucia adapts well to the informal setting, teaching Catalina Italian, while Juan prepares his daughter for their upcoming Constantinople journey by ensuring she becomes comfortable with riding and outdoor activities.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia blooms in the informal setting, her Ferrarese wit sharpening without the weight of court ceremony. You catch her one afternoon teaching Catalina Italian words for animals, your daughter solemnly repeating "cavallo" and "cane" with varying degrees of accuracy. exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I make sure Catalina gets accustomed to the outside and riding regularly. I explain to her that we will go on a journey that will last many days and that Catalina should learn to ride a horse along with papa and Lucia.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina receives this news with the grave attention she reserves for matters of supreme importance—the same expression she wears when inspecting a new wooden animal or deciding whether a particular food is acceptable.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Many days. On horses.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Yes. Many days on horses. We will see new places. Big water—the sea. Ships. But Catalina must learn to ride well. To hold tight. To be brave when she is tired.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She considers this for a long moment. Then, with the decisive confidence of a general accepting a commission:

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Catalina brave.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Over the following days, you establish a routine. Each morning, weather permitting, Catalina rides with you or Lucia—short circuits around the lodge at first, then gradually longer excursions along the roads and paths near Madrid. She learns to grip the mane properly, to lean into turns, to anticipate the horse's movements. She falls asleep in the saddle twice and nearly slips once—caught easily, but it teaches her that holding tight is not merely a suggestion. After that, her small fists clutch with genuine determination.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Tight. Hold tight.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: By the second week, she can manage an hour without complaint. By the third, nearly two—though she grows restless toward the end and requires distraction. Lucia proves skilled at this, pointing out birds, inventing games, singing fragments of Italian songs that Catalina attempts to mimic with enthusiastic inaccuracy. One afternoon, Catalina looks up at you from Hidalgo's back, her cheeks red from cold, her dark curls escaping from beneath her cap.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papá. Catalina... good rider?

encounters.recap: Juan spends two weeks at the Madrid lodge training young Princess Catalina to ride in preparation for the Constantinople journey. Starting with short circuits, she gradually builds endurance to handle two-hour rides, learning proper grip and balance while Lucia provides encouragement and distraction during the longer sessions.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The return to Toledo passes uneventfully—Catalina demonstrates her new riding endurance by lasting nearly the entire journey before demanding transfer to Lucia's arms for the final hour. She falls asleep before the Alcázar's towers come into view, and must be carried inside by Doña Beatriz, still clutching her small riding crop. Prince Fernando, now nearly four months old, has grown noticeably in your absence. The wet nurse reports he has been calm and content, sleeping well, beginning to focus on faces with evident interest. Doña Beatriz looks relieved to have the household reunited.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The next morning, you summon Álvaro to your study. He arrives with his customary efficiency, a leather satchel of documents under his arm. The weeks in Madrid have clearly not slowed the machinery of administration—the satchel looks full.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. I trust the retreat was restful?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I ask Alvaro if the fleet is assembled in Valencia. And if we can have a carriage for the Princess.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: The fleet assembles well. Eight transport vessels are already at anchor in Valencia—Genoese contracts, reliable captains. Two more expected by month's end. Capacity for the eight hundred crusaders, their horses, the household, and supplies for the crossing. The Santa Lucia will serve as the royal flagship. Newly fitted, spacious quarters for Your Majesties and the children. As for the carriage—I anticipated the need. A suitable vehicle is being prepared in Toledo as we speak. Enclosed, well-sprung, large enough for the Princess, a nurse, and one or two companions. It will slow the column somewhat on the road to Valencia, but not unacceptably. The Princess will travel with the column, then? Not remain in Toledo?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I refer of course to the flagship I had commissioned to be built. The one with the rooms for the queen, and named Princess Catalina. That ship should be ready by now right? Along with the other carracks.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Álvaro's expression shifts—a flicker of something that might be embarrassment, quickly suppressed beneath his usual composure.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Forgive me, Your Majesty. The Princess Catalina, yes. The flagship is complete. Launched in November, sea trials conducted in December. The shipwrights report she handles well—stable in heavy swells, spacious quarters as designed. The Queen's chambers are fitted as you specified. The other carracks of the new fleet... three of the five commissioned vessels are complete and seaworthy. The remaining two require another six to eight weeks—they will not be ready for the Constantinople expedition, but will join the fleet upon your return. So you have the Princess Catalina as flagship, three new carracks, and the eight Genoese transports under contract. More than sufficient for the expedition's needs. The Santa Lucia I mentioned is one of the Genoese vessels—I had assumed, incorrectly, that you might prefer a hired ship for the crossing rather than risk the new flagship on its maiden true voyage. But of course, the Princess Catalina was built precisely for this purpose. She should carry her namesake. I will ensure she is provisioned and ready at Valencia. The royal quarters will be prepared for Your Majesties, the Princess, and Prince Fernando—unless the Prince remains in Toledo?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Lucia, who of your donna's will come? And what portugese dona's will we take with us? Have you given this thought?

encounters.recap: Juan returns to Toledo and meets with Álvaro to plan the Constantinople expedition. The fleet is nearly ready in Valencia, including the newly completed flagship Princess Catalina. Juan begins discussing which courtiers will accompany the royal family on the voyage.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. I trust the retreat was restful?
